If someone verifies him as a heretic the likes of Kenneth Copeland, I‚Äôll rightfully call that out. We‚Äôre not ‚Äúpartnered‚Äù but not enemies.
@bookkeepPLUS You may benefit from listening to the episode and defining terms and scenarios prudently. I‚Äôd encourage you to do so. God bless!

@nightlightoasis If someone was ever abused in a church (I hate that this happens) & if it was poorly handled, I‚Äôd be heart broken, but still delineate between bad leadership decisions and what is actually defined as partnership with false teachers. This podcast episode is about the latter.

The irony of all ironies ‚Äî or perhaps the hypocrisy of all hypocrisies ‚Äî is to call out false teachers while partnering with them for any purpose. 

Evangelize them? Yes. Partnerships that tolerate or even advance them? May it never be. https://t.co/F1ncnL3bBO

@danielwalbert @Justin_Bond 6. Local church is central. Most of the questions and content comes out of real needs that arise in our local church. we want to meet those needs. 

7. Spread it out. I wrote Holy Spirit book out of joyful study over the last 10 months. Some late nights, but mostly bit by bit.

@danielwalbert 5. Buuuut then there‚Äôs a team. People like @Justin_Bond take my 30 minutes of work on a video and spend hours making it amazing & posting, meanwhile, I‚Äôm at a counseling session or shepherding a staff member. 

Using our gifts together makes it easier. Never a ‚Äúone man‚Äù show.

@danielwalbert 4. Timing. For example, I wrote my children‚Äôs book during morning coffee times on a vacation with my wife (my co author). The kids chimed in. We had a great time. Then, it was done. Meanwhile, it comes out same time as a video or podcast that came from prior study notes. 

Cont‚Ä¶

@danielwalbert Lots of factors to consider. 

1. Varying capacities.

2. Team. Who is helping? 

3. Teaching. Is he making fresh content for each medium or using content from his study that he couldn‚Äôt always fit in 40 minute sermon? Recycling is wise. 

1/2
@thegodwardlife Yes!

Healthy churches & ministries will have this pattern of growth:

1. Unity in the Spirit

2. Diversity in their gifts 

3. Maturity in the faith

Preaching on spiritual gifts this weekend and reminded of this truth:

No Christian and no ministry is self-made. Christ gives gifts and those gifts work together to build up the body. 

‚ÄúYou can do this on your own‚Äù is a phrase rooted in self-centered ambition & pride.

Manly things real men do:

1. Praying daily
2. Studying Scripture diligently
3. Working hard to provide
4. Loving a wife sacrificially
5. Shepherding children biblically
6. Giving to your church generously
7. Making disciples consistently
8. Speaking truth boldly

What else?

One of the most manly things you could ever do is be consistent (reliable).

Consistency sets the men apart from the boys, the pros from the amateurs, and the one hit wonders from the seasoned leaders.

In a world filled with flakes, God‚Äôs men are called to uncommon consistency.

The best way to reach Gen Z is the same way every generation gets reached: preach the true & undiluted gospel. 

Pragmatism puts on a new mask every 10 years, and what we‚Äôre seeing now is nothing new. 

Don‚Äôt cater, call. 

Don‚Äôt pander, preach.

@lawsonharlow As a younger pastor I‚Äôm seeing a consistent theme in which churches are so desperate to be excepted by Gen Z that they are jumping through all the hoops and catering to them with pragmatism and shallow easy believism. 

It‚Äôs the new church growth movement, catering to culture.

In this wicked generation, preach the gospel again, again, and again. It is the only power that can save them.
